string-array.item:
DAYS & SCHEDULE: The app displays ongoing events with a green background, future events yellow, and ended events gray. Start scrolling to view a scrollbar on the right side of the page, then quickly jump to any day. Select a day to expand or collapse every hour for that day and view your schedule for each hour. Touch the star to the left of an event to add it to "My Events" list at the top of each day and the "Starred" tab to the left. View your events, event notes and tournament finishes by clicking on the "My Data" tab or swiping to the right from the Schedule tab. 

SEARCHING: The magnifier icon shows a list of all games and allows you to either select a specific game or type in search words. You can search for and select a tournament to view and/or star all of its events. For example, to find every Power Grid event, type "Power" and select "Power Grid" from the list, or type "Power Grid" and hit search. Or to view every demo event in the convention, type "Demo" and hit search. If you want to view all the tournaments and filter down the list to your favorites, use "Filter Schedule" from the main menu. 

SAVING: App settings, tournament finishes, event notes, etc. are all saved automatically, so do not worry about losing your settings! 

OTHER: For tournament finishes, finishes awarding plaques are in bold while laurels are in italics. 

Please contact Jeff Finkeldey at dev@boardgamers.org with any further questions.

The schedule on the main screen is a chronological listing of events by order of appearance. Junior Events are listed first, highlighted by a symbol and are in green. Open Gaming, including Scheduled Open Games (SOG), and other non-tournament games are listed in orange. Nongaming events, such as meetings, registration, and the auction, are listed in blue. Seminars are listed in purple. Demonstrations are listed in black, italics. Advanced rounds that require prior qualification, such as Finals, are listed in red. \n\nWhen more than one event starts at the same time, non-tournament events are listed first, followed by tournaments—both in alphabetical order. An alphabetical list of tournaments can be found in search screen via the main menu.

Abbreviations for dates are Mo: Monday, Tu: Tuesday, We: Wednesday, Th: Thursday, Fr: Friday, Sa: Saturday, Su: Sunday, SMo: Second Monday. "SMo" indicates that events occur on the Monday after WBC ends.

Times are listed in military time; e.g., 11 or 1100 is 11 am and 13 or 1300 is 1 pm. Tournament play commences at the scheduled times for each event and may run past midnight. No event may start a round after midnight (exception: our five night enders) or reconvene before 9 am without the consent of all remaining players.

“H1/3” indicates the heat number out of the total number of heats. “R1/6” indicates the round number out of the estimated total number of rounds. A “-” instead of a “/” in the Round listing indicates that the rounds are continuous, starting immediately after the end of the preceding round. Heats are multiple starts of an event’s preliminary (qualifying) round. Players may play in as many heats as they wish, win or lose. Rounds often require players to qualify to advance to the next round. Players wishing to withdraw even if they qualify for the next round should inform the GM. Players who wish to enter an event in an advanced round must have the permission of the GM.

Play is restricted to players who have qualified for these rounds. For “SF/F,” the Final immediately follows the semifinal. Final rounds may be rescheduled by the GM for the mutual benefit of the finalists. Such rescheduling requires the agreement of ALL remaining players without pressure to do so, otherwise the scheduled time is the default. Those who can’t abide by it must forfeit. Players who fail to appear for advanced rounds forfeit any claim on prizes or laurels that pass instead to those who advance in their place.
1, 2, 3, 4, 5 or 6 is the number of places receiving plaques; 2 through 6 are Century events.

All teaching sessions take place in the Exhibit Hall Annex at the listed Table #. For B Class Events, anyone new to a game must attend. For C Class Event s, attending a scheduled demo places less stress on the GM and the event. If no one arrives for a demo within 15 minutes of the scheduled starting time, the demo may be cancelled. This year, Previews and have been added to the demo area. Previews are demos without a corresponding event; designers showing their upcoming games either as an adjunct to anticipated Kick Starter campaigns or extended playtesting opportunities. Doing so in the Demo area allows us to relieve pressure on the Open Gaming area while at the same time benefiting everyone with scheduled opportunities to gather players without tying up tables trolling for interest.

FORMAT: Before playing an event, check the Event Preview at http://www.boardgamers.org/wbc23/previews-2023.html, the event kiosk, or via the tournament screen in the app by selecting an event or searching for that tournament. The Event Preview contains the details about how the event will run, any special tournament rules, the number of players who qualify to advance, and any tie-breakers in use. Most events become SE during subsequent rounds. Any questions about format should be directed to the GM BEFORE the event begins. Standard tie-breakers apply to events run with heats. They are described on our website’s GM Guidelines page and in event Previews. 

FF: Free Form—Contact GM at the listed times for flexible scheduling. 

SE: Single Elimination—play until you lose one game. 

SEM: SE with Mulligan Round—the Mulligan is an optional Round 1 that forgives losses. Winners advance directly to Round 2. Non-winners may play again in the regularly scheduled Round 1 with no penalty. 

SWISS: Play all rounds paired against those with same record. 

SwEl: Swiss Elimination—play all preliminary rounds; qualifiers advance to SE rounds. 

HWO: Heat Winners Only—enter any number of preliminary heats; winners advance to next round. 

HMSE: Heats Multiple SE—each heat is played SE in continuous rounds to determine one winner who advances to the next round. 

HMW-T: Heats Most Wins — Timing. Enter any number of heats; qualifiers advance to SE rounds; first tiebreaker is most wins (e.g., total in all heats entered). The remaining tiebreakers are 2) timing of first win (first, second, third, fourth heat, etc.); 3) fewest number of heats entered; 4) most second places; 5) fewest total points behind first place in second place finishes; 6) Fewest total points behind first place in all finishes; 7) highest total points ahead of second place; 8) high dice roll. 

HMW-P: Heats Most Wins — Points. Enter any number of heats; qualifiers advance to SE rounds; first tiebreaker is most wins (e.g., total in all heats entered). The remaining tiebreakers are 2) total points in all heats (1000 for 1st place, 100 for 2nd, 10 for 3rd, 1 for 4th); 3) GM specific tie-breaker; 4) high dice roll. 

Preview: Non-event demonstration.
The duration of the event in hours. Round lengths are rounded up to the next hour. Actual allowed playing time is determined by the GM and should always be less than the scheduled period.

If an image of two rotating arrows appears in the Length column, the event continues immediately into the next round upon completion of a round. The only interruption is at midnight, when rounds continue the following morning at 9. GMs may grant breaks between rounds of no more than one hour, but only if the event is on schedule and such breaks are applied uniformly for all entrants, such that each round starts and ends simultaneously (e.g., some players may not be allowed a break that allows them to trail the rest of the field and delay the tournament).

A map—displaying a multilevel floorplan of Seven Springs Resort—is shown on every event description screen. The room for the event will flash green. Continuous round Events spanning multiple days start again the next day in the same room unless listed elsewhere in the schedule.
